abstract_summ: After adjusting for covariates, US counties with a higher proportion of the black population, and a higher proportion of adults with less than high school diploma had disproportionately higher COVID-19 cases and deaths ({beta}>0, p<0.05).Counties with higher proportions of black residents had more COVID-19 diagnoses (RR 1.24, 95% CI 1.17-1.33) and deaths (RR 1.18, 95% CI 1.00-1.40), after adjusting for county-level characteristics such as age, poverty, comorbidities, and epidemic duration.Counties with higher proportions of black residents had more COVID-19 diagnoses (RR 1.24, 95% CI 1.17-1.33) and deaths (RR 1.18, 95% CI 1.00-1.40), after adjusting for county-level characteristics such as age, poverty, comorbidities, and epidemic duration.We obtained datasets on COVID-19 cases and deaths, and racial population totals, by US county.These findings suggest targeted health policies to support individuals living in poor housing conditions should be considered in further efforts to mitigate adverse outcomes associated with COVID19.Purpose Given incomplete data reporting by race, we used data on COVID-19 cases and deaths in US counties to describe racial disparities in COVID-19 disease and death and associated determinants.
title_summ: Association of Poor Housing Conditions with COVID-19 Incidence and Mortality Across US CountiesAssessing Differential Impacts of COVID-19 on Black CommunitiesBlacks/African Americans are 5 Times More Likely to Develop COVID-19: Spatial Modeling of New York City ZIP Code-level Testing ResultsAssessing COVID-19 Risk, Vulnerability and Infection Prevalence in CommunitiesEthnics and economics in COVID-19: Meta-regression of data from countries in the New York metropolitan areaCounty-Level Proportions of Black and Hispanic populations, and Socioeconomic Characteristics in Association with Confirmed COVID-19 Cases and Deaths in the United StatesU.S. county-level characteristics to inform equitable COVID-19 responseAssessing Differential Impacts of COVID-19 on Black CommunitiesRacial demographics and COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths: a correlational analysis of 2886 US countiesDisparities in COVID-19 Testing and Positivity in New York CityCommunity and Socioeconomic Factors Associated with COVID-19 in the United States: Zip code level cross sectional analysis
